page.title: 01Southern end of Loch Ken
page.content: This area is thinly populated and supports a few small farms. These stock mainly sheep and beef cattle, which graze the land. There is little deciduous woodland left in an area that was once densely covered in native trees such as oak and birch. Much of the woodland is now made up of faster growing conifers such as spruce. Come winter much of the wildlife can be seen feeding alonside the farm livestock and the now dominant conifers will support many birds, squirrels and deer. Several flocks of migratory geese return each winter from Greenland and Spitzbergen. The loch is popular with both anglers and water sports enthusiasts. Coarse and salmon fishermen take to the water when the windsurfers and skiers leave at the end of the summer.
